subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material. According to Pavia (1976) , the type specimens of
Turritella fasciata Borson, 1821
and
Turritella funiculata Borson, 1821
are lost. The plate caption for the specimen illustrated by Sacco (1996, pl. 3, fig 17a) as
Protoma cathedralis var. funiculata
, however, states: ‘es. tip. Coll. Borson’. Therefore, the specimen BS.061.07.006, stored in the collection of the Museo Regionale di Scienze Naturali Torino, was part of Borson’s collection and most probably represents a syntype or even the holotype . Merlino & Campanino (2002) list this specimen as syntype .

Studied material. 2 spec. NHMW 1862/0049/0026, 3 spec. NHMW 1854/0016/0209,
7 spec. NHMW 1862/0035/0454, Torino ( Italy ) (the preservation suggests Baldissero as locality)
.

Illustrated material.
Fig. 25I
: NHMW 1862/0049/0026, SL: 94.3 mm , MD: 20.4 mm ; Fig. 25J : NHMW 1854/0016/0209 SL: 80.9 mm , MD: 26.3 mm .

Discussion. The first description of Italian specimens that we consider as representatives of
Allmonia
was published by Borson (1821) as
Turritella fasciata
and
T. funiculata
from the Burdigalian of the Torino Hills.
Turritella fasciata
was already preoccupied for an Eocene species described by Lamarck (1804) but
Turritella funiculata
was an available name. Borson (1821) provided a short description and a rather sketchy illustration. Brongniart (1823) was aware of this name but rejected its use by referring to the poor illustration in Borson (1821) and synonymized these with his
Turritella cathedralis
. Sacco (1895) restored Borson’s taxa as variation-names (≈ subspecies) of
Protoma cathedralis
as exfasciata (replacement name for
fasciata
) and
funiculata
. Cossmann (1912) and Cossmann & Peyrot (1922) argued that the Italian Miocene specimens were different from the French
cathedralis
and pointed out that
funiculata
was an available name for the Italian species. Finally, Pavia (1976) discussed
funiculata
as an available name to replace some of Sacco’s variety names. In respect to this literature record,
Turritella funiculata
cannot be treated as nomen oblitum . Sacco (1895) described numerous additional variation names of
P. cathedralis
, which all derive from the Burdigalian locality Baldissero in the Torino Hills ( Italy ). Therefore, we tentatively treat all these taxa as morphotypes of a single, very variable species for which
Turritella funiculata
is the oldest available name.

Distribution. Proto-Mediterranean Sea. Burdigalian (early Miocene): Torino Hills : Baldissero ( Italy ). A fragmentary specimen illustrated by Stefanini (1916) from the Tortonian of the Veneto region in northern Italy would be the stratigraphically youngest record.
